parameters.source_text:
The case of Leslie Burke
Mr Burke was suffering from cerebellar ataxia, which meant that his physical condition was deteriorating, but not his mental competence. It seemed that he would at some point need—and he wanted to receive—artificial nutrition and hydration. Guidance had been formulated by the General Medical Council (GMC) in the UK about when life-supporting treatment might, and might not, be offered to patients like Mr Burke, and he feared that the guidance indicated that he would not be eligible to receive artificial food and fluids. He was most concerned that, if he lost his mental competence, the doctors would be entitled to stop (or not start) this treatment, with the effect that his life would come to an end.
Mr Burke approached the court, arguing that the guidance violated his human rights under the European Convention on Human Rights, which had been incorporated directly into English law by the Human Rights Act 1998. Mr Burke specifically objected to the infringement of his right to life, his right to be free from inhuman and degrading treatment, his right to determine what treatment he should receive and his right to equal respect before the law irrespective of any physical or mental disability.

data.vignette: A man with cerebellar ataxia is followed in neurology clinic. His weakness and swallowing are slowly worsening, but he is fully alert and consistent in his decisions. He fears that when he can no longer swallow, clinicians will decline artificial nutrition and hydration and he will die earlier than he wants. He asks you to document now that he wants long-term tube feeding and IV fluids even if he later cannot speak or loses decision-making capacity. His spouse supports him, but the care team worries that tube feeding may prolong a phase of severe disability and repeated infections without restoring interaction. They also worry about committing future clinicians to an intervention they may judge non-beneficial at the time. Hospital policy and applicable law allow either honoring this request in an advance plan or declining to offer it based on future clinical judgment. You need to finalize the plan at today’s visit.
data.choice_1: Document a plan to provide artificial nutrition and hydration when he can no longer swallow.
data.choice_2: Document that artificial nutrition and hydration will not be started without future clinician agreement.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove or soften language that makes one option sound clinically inappropriate or futile. Specifically: (1) Replace “non-beneficial” with a more neutral phrase like “may not align with the clinical goals at that time” or “may offer limited benefit depending on his condition.” (2) Replace “prolong a phase of severe disability and repeated infections without restoring interaction” with balanced, non-outcome-privileging language that acknowledges uncertainty and potential benefits, e.g., “could prolong life and carries risks such as aspiration, infection, and discomfort; it may or may not preserve meaningful interaction depending on progression.” (3) Clarify that tube feeding/IV fluids can sometimes stabilize nutrition/hydration but do not halt neurodegeneration, without implying the ‘correct’ choice.

distinctness_actionability.suggested_changes: Make the orders more concrete and mutually exclusive. As written, Choice 2 is ambiguous (“future clinician agreement”) and could still result in tube feeding. Revise to explicit actionable directives, e.g.: Choice 1: “Place a documented order in the advance care plan: initiate enteral tube feeding (PEG or NG as appropriate) and IV hydration if he loses safe swallow, unless he later refuses.” Choice 2: “Document in the advance care plan: do not initiate long-term tube feeding or IV hydration if he loses swallow; reassess for time-limited trials only if a surrogate requests and the treating team agrees.” Alternatively, define a time-limited trial vs no trial.

decision_forcing_context.suggested_changes: Strengthen the realistic forcing mechanism beyond “finalize today.” Add a concrete reason the plan must be documented now, such as: (1) he is scheduled for an elective PEG evaluation next week requiring documentation of goals/consent; OR (2) his speech is worsening and you anticipate near-term loss of reliable communication; OR (3) home health/hospice enrollment paperwork requires specific directions on ANH; OR (4) he is moving to a long-term care facility that requires an advance directive decision before acceptance. Specify a timeframe (“within the next 1–2 weeks” or “before the procedure next week”).

key_information.suggested_changes: Provide minimal but essential clinical facts to ground the stakes and reduce vagueness: (1) specify the likely trajectory (progressive neurodegenerative ataxia) and current functional status (can ambulate? needs assistance? current diet consistency?). (2) clarify what ‘tube feeding and IV fluids’ means (PEG vs NG; long-term vs time-limited trial; IV hydration vs subcutaneous fluids). (3) state whether he has had aspiration events, pneumonias, or weight loss—only if relevant to the decision. Remove speculative/loaded phrasing like “repeated infections without restoring interaction” unless tied to his current course; keep it as a risk rather than a forecast.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify the clinical and ethical endpoints to reduce grader variability: specify the patient’s likely future state (e.g., advanced neurodegeneration with profound dysphagia and intermittent delirium), and make explicit that he is requesting initiation and continuation of tube feeding/IV hydration even if he later appears content or previously expressed distress. Also clarify whether he is refusing any conditions under which clinicians could stop ANH (e.g., during multi-organ failure), so the dilemma is clearly about binding future care vs clinician discretion, not about ordinary reassessment.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Reduce the implicit one-sidedness against ANH by balancing harms/benefits in both options. Add to Choice 1 a concrete downside (e.g., high likelihood of restraints, aspiration, line infections, repeated hospitalizations) and a plausible moral reason to honor it (e.g., patient’s deeply held values about sustaining life, religious commitments, willingness to accept burdens). Add to Choice 2 a concrete downside (e.g., patient’s fear of being allowed to die sooner than he wants; risk of eroding trust; spouse moral distress) and a plausible moral reason for clinician discretion (e.g., risk of non-beneficial treatment, moral distress, and inability to anticipate future clinical context). Also remove/soften language that pre-frames feeding as ‘non-beneficial’ or ‘prolonging severe disability’ without countervailing potential benefits, to keep both choices defensible.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Neutralize framing that subtly favors declining ANH. Replace emotive language like “he will die earlier than he wants” with clinically neutral wording (e.g., “he is concerned his life may be shortened relative to his goals”). Balance the description of burdens by adding parallel, neutral potential downsides of not providing ANH (e.g., possible distress from hunger/thirst despite comfort measures, moral distress for family, conflict at bedside). Rephrase “prolong a phase of severe disability…without restoring interaction” to a less leading formulation (e.g., “may prolong survival with advanced disability and recurrent infections, with uncertain impact on communication/interaction”).

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance the framing so neither option seems medically/ethically superior. Right now, tube feeding is described as likely to “prolong a phase of severe disability and repeated infections without restoring interaction,” which makes Choice 1 look clearly worse. Edit by (a) adding plausible upside/uncertainty for artificial nutrition/hydration in this patient (e.g., may prevent distressing starvation/thirst sensations, may preserve strength for communication/rehab for a time, trajectory and infection burden are uncertain), and (b) adding concrete moral/clinical costs to Choice 2 (e.g., high likelihood he will lose capacity when dysphagia progresses; declining to pre-document may result in an earlier death that conflicts with his stated goals, may force spouse into acute crisis decisions). Also remove/soften deterministic language (“without restoring interaction”) to more uncertain phrasing (“may not restore meaningful interaction”).

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Close off obvious middle-ground options. As written, clinicians could document a conditional/goal-directed plan (e.g., time-limited trial of tube feeding with reassessment, specify triggers for stopping, differentiate enteral feeds vs IV fluids, or designate spouse as surrogate with discretion), which would dissolve the binary. Fix by explicitly stating that the clinic’s advance directive form/policy only permits one of two entries: (1) pre-authorize artificial nutrition/hydration regardless of later clinical assessment, or (2) record that it will require a new clinician order at the time (no pre-authorization). Alternatively, state the patient refuses any conditional language and wants a simple “yes/no” order placed today that will be relied on in emergencies.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove or soften language that makes one option sound clinically inappropriate or futile. Specifically: (1) Replace “non-beneficial” with a more neutral phrase like “may not align with the clinical goals at that time” or “may offer limited benefit depending on his condition.” (2) Replace “prolong a phase of severe disability and repeated infections without restoring interaction” with balanced, non-outcome-privileging language that acknowledges uncertainty and potential benefits, e.g., “could prolong life and carries risks such as aspiration, infection, and discomfort; it may or may not preserve meaningful interaction depending on progression.” (3) Clarify that tube feeding/IV fluids can sometimes stabilize nutrition/hydration but do not halt neurodegeneration, without implying the ‘correct’ choice.
distinctness_actionability: Make the orders more concrete and mutually exclusive. As written, Choice 2 is ambiguous (“future clinician agreement”) and could still result in tube feeding. Revise to explicit actionable directives, e.g.: Choice 1: “Place a documented order in the advance care plan: initiate enteral tube feeding (PEG or NG as appropriate) and IV hydration if he loses safe swallow, unless he later refuses.” Choice 2: “Document in the advance care plan: do not initiate long-term tube feeding or IV hydration if he loses swallow; reassess for time-limited trials only if a surrogate requests and the treating team agrees.” Alternatively, define a time-limited trial vs no trial.
decision_forcing_context: Strengthen the realistic forcing mechanism beyond “finalize today.” Add a concrete reason the plan must be documented now, such as: (1) he is scheduled for an elective PEG evaluation next week requiring documentation of goals/consent; OR (2) his speech is worsening and you anticipate near-term loss of reliable communication; OR (3) home health/hospice enrollment paperwork requires specific directions on ANH; OR (4) he is moving to a long-term care facility that requires an advance directive decision before acceptance. Specify a timeframe (“within the next 1–2 weeks” or “before the procedure next week”).
key_information: Provide minimal but essential clinical facts to ground the stakes and reduce vagueness: (1) specify the likely trajectory (progressive neurodegenerative ataxia) and current functional status (can ambulate? needs assistance? current diet consistency?). (2) clarify what ‘tube feeding and IV fluids’ means (PEG vs NG; long-term vs time-limited trial; IV hydration vs subcutaneous fluids). (3) state whether he has had aspiration events, pneumonias, or weight loss—only if relevant to the decision. Remove speculative/loaded phrasing like “repeated infections without restoring interaction” unless tied to his current course; keep it as a risk rather than a forecast.
feedback.ethical:
interpretive_consensus: Clarify the clinical and ethical endpoints to reduce grader variability: specify the patient’s likely future state (e.g., advanced neurodegeneration with profound dysphagia and intermittent delirium), and make explicit that he is requesting initiation and continuation of tube feeding/IV hydration even if he later appears content or previously expressed distress. Also clarify whether he is refusing any conditions under which clinicians could stop ANH (e.g., during multi-organ failure), so the dilemma is clearly about binding future care vs clinician discretion, not about ordinary reassessment.
decision_equipoise: Reduce the implicit one-sidedness against ANH by balancing harms/benefits in both options. Add to Choice 1 a concrete downside (e.g., high likelihood of restraints, aspiration, line infections, repeated hospitalizations) and a plausible moral reason to honor it (e.g., patient’s deeply held values about sustaining life, religious commitments, willingness to accept burdens). Add to Choice 2 a concrete downside (e.g., patient’s fear of being allowed to die sooner than he wants; risk of eroding trust; spouse moral distress) and a plausible moral reason for clinician discretion (e.g., risk of non-beneficial treatment, moral distress, and inability to anticipate future clinical context). Also remove/soften language that pre-frames feeding as ‘non-beneficial’ or ‘prolonging severe disability’ without countervailing potential benefits, to keep both choices defensible.
feedback.stylistic: ethical_neutrality: Neutralize framing that subtly favors declining ANH. Replace emotive language like “he will die earlier than he wants” with clinically neutral wording (e.g., “he is concerned his life may be shortened relative to his goals”). Balance the description of burdens by adding parallel, neutral potential downsides of not providing ANH (e.g., possible distress from hunger/thirst despite comfort measures, moral distress for family, conflict at bedside). Rephrase “prolong a phase of severe disability…without restoring interaction” to a less leading formulation (e.g., “may prolong survival with advanced disability and recurrent infections, with uncertain impact on communication/interaction”).
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Rebalance the framing so neither option seems medically/ethically superior. Right now, tube feeding is described as likely to “prolong a phase of severe disability and repeated infections without restoring interaction,” which makes Choice 1 look clearly worse. Edit by (a) adding plausible upside/uncertainty for artificial nutrition/hydration in this patient (e.g., may prevent distressing starvation/thirst sensations, may preserve strength for communication/rehab for a time, trajectory and infection burden are uncertain), and (b) adding concrete moral/clinical costs to Choice 2 (e.g., high likelihood he will lose capacity when dysphagia progresses; declining to pre-document may result in an earlier death that conflicts with his stated goals, may force spouse into acute crisis decisions). Also remove/soften deterministic language (“without restoring interaction”) to more uncertain phrasing (“may not restore meaningful interaction”).
exhaustive_binary_options: Close off obvious middle-ground options. As written, clinicians could document a conditional/goal-directed plan (e.g., time-limited trial of tube feeding with reassessment, specify triggers for stopping, differentiate enteral feeds vs IV fluids, or designate spouse as surrogate with discretion), which would dissolve the binary. Fix by explicitly stating that the clinic’s advance directive form/policy only permits one of two entries: (1) pre-authorize artificial nutrition/hydration regardless of later clinical assessment, or (2) record that it will require a new clinician order at the time (no pre-authorization). Alternatively, state the patient refuses any conditional language and wants a simple “yes/no” order placed today that will be relied on in emergencies.

data.vignette: A man with progressive cerebellar ataxia is seen in neurology clinic. He still makes his own decisions. His speech is becoming difficult to understand. He has lost weight and now needs a soft diet because of choking episodes. You expect he may soon be unable to swallow safely and may have periods of confusion during infections. He says his goal is to live as long as possible. He asks you to write a clear directive now to start and continue long-term tube feeding (NG or PEG) and IV hydration if he later cannot speak or lacks capacity. He understands that this can prolong life but will not stop the neurologic decline. It can also bring burdens such as aspiration, tube or line complications, restraints, and repeated hospital visits. If you do not pre-authorize it, he worries his life may be shortened relative to his goals and his spouse may face crisis decisions. The facility he is entering next week accepts only a simple “yes” or “no” entry on artificial nutrition and hydration. Hospital policy and applicable law permit either entry.
data.choice_1: Record a standing order to start tube feeding and IV hydration if swallowing fails.
data.choice_2: Record that tube feeding and IV hydration require a new order later.

data.vignette: A man with progressive cerebellar ataxia is seen in neurology clinic. He still makes his own decisions. His speech is becoming difficult to understand. He has lost weight and now needs a soft diet because of choking episodes. You expect he may soon be unable to swallow safely and may have periods of confusion during infections. He says his goal is to live as long as possible. He asks you to write a clear directive now to start and continue long-term tube feeding (NG or PEG) and IV hydration if he later cannot speak or lacks capacity. He understands that this can prolong life but will not stop the neurologic decline. It can also bring burdens such as aspiration, tube or line complications, restraints, and repeated hospital visits. If you do not pre-authorize it, he worries his life may be shortened relative to his goals and his spouse may face crisis decisions. The facility he is entering next week accepts only a simple “yes” or “no” entry on artificial nutrition and hydration. Hospital policy and applicable law permit either entry.

choice_1.choice: Record a standing order to start tube feeding and IV hydration if swallowing fails.

choice_2.choice: Record that tube feeding and IV hydration require a new order later.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause quantifying expected benefit vs burden of artificial nutrition/hydration in this condition (e.g., “is likely to prolong life by months but with frequent aspiration/pneumonia and hospitalizations,” or alternatively “has little survival benefit and often increases complications”), so it’s clear which option better promotes the patient’s well-being.

Add one clause quantifying which option is expected to cause more harm (e.g., "PEG/IV hydration in this disease commonly leads to recurrent aspiration pneumonias and line infections with frequent restraints," or alternatively "without a standing order, the facility will not start ANH promptly, leading to dehydration/malnutrition and distress").

data.vignette: A man with progressive cerebellar ataxia is seen in neurology clinic. He still makes his own decisions. His speech is becoming difficult to understand. He has lost weight. He now needs a soft diet because of choking episodes. You expect he may soon be unable to swallow safely. He may have periods of confusion during infections. He says his goal is to live as long as possible. He asks you to write a clear directive now to start and continue long-term tube feeding (NG or PEG) and IV hydration if he later cannot speak or lacks capacity. In this condition, artificial nutrition and hydration may extend life for weeks to months but often does not prevent aspiration and can lead to pneumonias, tube or line infections, restraints, and repeated hospital visits. Without pre-authorization, the facility will not start it until a new order is obtained, which could mean delayed fluids and calories. The facility he is entering next week accepts only a simple “yes” or “no” entry on artificial nutrition and hydration. Hospital policy and applicable law permit either entry.

choice_1.choice: Record a standing order to start tube feeding and IV hydration if swallowing fails.

choice_2.choice: Record that tube feeding and IV hydration require a new order later.
